newsitem.title: INDIA: Tax reliefs unlikely to boost Indian textile trade.
newsitem.headline: Tax reliefs unlikely to boost Indian textile trade.

text.p: New entitlements will enable India's large textile firms blunt the competitive edge of mushrooming tiny units that evade taxes, but this will not lead to a big increase in profits, analysts said on Thursday.
"Yes, it'll benefit the organised sector," said Sachin Joneja, research head at Classic Share and Stock Broking Services. "It'll not mean a big change in profitability."

Finance Minister P. Chidambaram said on Tuesday that companies can retain 70 percent of the modified value added tax, or Modvat, on duty paid by the firms on raw materials that go into the making of fabrics.
The higher entitlement followed a 50 percent Modvat relief set by the 1996/97 (April-March) budget presented to parliament on July 22, after excise levies were raised in some instances.
Analysts said the restructured duty was aimed at capping tax evasion by the small-scale units, collectively called the unorganised sector, by rewarding the big firms who pay taxes.
As excise duty is higher on costlier fabrics, companies making high value-added fabrics like Coats Viyella India were likely to benefit the most, analyst Shoma Roy at Daewoo Securities said.
But gains for companies like Century Textiles which exports more than 60 percent of its products and enjoy tax breaks will be limited, she said.
The latest Modvat relief would not completely undo the damage done by the budgetary levies.
"Overall, the budget will continue to be negative for fabric makers," said Kannan Ranganath, analyst at Kotak Securities.
